title: Mass No. 1 (Schubert)
text:
Mass No. 1 in <a href="F%20major">F major</a>, 105, is a <a href="mass%20%28music%29">mass</a> composed by <a href="Franz%20Schubert">Franz Schubert</a> in 1814. It is scored for two <a href="soprano">soprano</a> <a href="solo%20%28music%29">soloist</a>s, two <a href="tenor">tenor</a> soloists, <a href="alto">alto</a> and <a href="bass%20%28voice%20type%29">bass</a> soloists, <a href="SATB">SATB</a> choir, <a href="oboe">oboe</a>, <a href="clarinet">clarinet</a>, <a href="bassoon">bassoon</a>, 2 <a href="French%20horn">horn</a>s, <a href="violin">violin</a> I and II, <a href="viola">viola</a>, and (<a href="cello">cello</a>, <a href="double%20bass">double bass</a> and <a href="pipe%20organ">organ</a>). It was the first of Schubert's masses to be performed, and is of the "" type.
Background.
The mass was composed for the centennial celebration of the parish church of <a href="Lichtental">Lichtental</a>, now part of Vienna. The Schuberts' family church, it is also known as "" (Schubert church). Schubert received an invitation to compose a mass for the anniversary in May 1814. The premiere was conducted on 25 September with an estimated 62 performers, a large contingent for contemporary performances. The composer's brother <a href="Ferdinand%20Schubert">Ferdinand</a> played the organ, Michael Holzer served as <a href="choirmaster">choirmaster</a>, <a href="Joseph%20Mayseder">Joseph Mayseder</a> served as <a href="concertmaster">concertmaster</a>, <a href="Therese%20Grob">Therese Grob</a> sang the soprano solo, and Schubert conducted. Schubert's teacher <a href="Antonio%20Salieri">Antonio Salieri</a> may have attended the premiere; afterwards, he is said to have embraced his student with the words "" ("You will bring me yet more honour").
Ferdinand wrote that a second performance took place ten days later at <a href="Augustinian%20Church%2C%20Vienna">St Augustine's Court Church</a>, before a prestigious audience that may have included foreign dignitaries.
Schubert's love for Therese Grob may have been kindled during the writing of this mass. The prominent first soprano solo, with its high <a href="tessitura">tessitura</a>, was designed to showcase her voice.
Schubert composed an alternative "" (formerly 185) in April 1815. This may have been composed for a service during the public outcry over <a href="Hundred%20Days">Napoleon's escape from Elba</a>; alternatively, it may have been for a second performance of the mass at the Lichtental church on <a href="Trinity%20Sunday">Trinity Sunday</a>. It replaces a shorter, less <a href="fugue">fugal</a> section in the 1814 version.
Structure.
The piece is divided into six <a href="movement%20%28music%29">movement</a>s. Performances require approximately 40 minutes. Notes are based on Schubert's 1815 revision.
